overview_of_class: The flow of migrants away from war, famine and economic hardship is one of the most significant stories of our time. Across the globe, millions of people are on the move, straining the capacity of governments and international relief organizations to cope and ordinary citizens to comprehend. In the United States, France, Germany and much of Europe, the recent flow of humanity from the Middle East, in particular, has become a prominent social and political issue, prompting profound questions about how to respond. This class explores the origins of the current refugee crisis and its ongoing evolution, paying attention to disparate voices and interests. You will polish skills in research/reporting, interviewing and critical thinking as you work toward meaningful final projects in an array of media. Open to graduates and undergraduates, the class is a prerequisite for BSJ students chosen to travel to France or MSJ students chosen to travel to Germany in June 2016.

overview_of_class: In this course, you will focus on an important facet of journalism: investigating potentially wrongful convictions. This class isn't about theory; it's about pursuing the truth about real murder cases, interviewing skittish sources in often tough neighborhoods and prisoners serving time?sometimes decades?for crimes they say they didn't commit. You will be introduced to a variety of investigative techniques, interviewing skills, approaches to developing sources and employing public records and databases. Of paramount importance in this class: your safety and adhering to the highest ethical standards in journalism. You are expected to devote a tremendous amount of time in the field?weekdays and weekends?doing real shoe-leather journalism, knocking on doors, digging for information and determining whether there has been a miscarriage of justice. Keep in mind: Investigative reporting is hard. Expect to confront roadblocks. Anticipate spinning your wheels. There will be frustrations and setbacks. And along the way, hopefully, you will learn to think like an investigative reporter, you will learn by doing and you will do it by the most honorable methods and, so, come closer to discovering the truth?whatever that truth is. Prof. Klein is assisted in class by a licensed private detective and a research associate who works for The Medill Justice Project. Please see www.medilljusticeproject.org for more information.

overview_of_class: Sports Marketing provides an understanding of the key concepts and methods in marketing communications in both traditional and digital media within the world of sports. The course provides students with the development and execution of communications strategies for any sports organization with added opportunities to learn the marketing environments that pertain to sports including organizations, leagues and brands. Primary emphasis is placed on consumer engagement, branding, market segmentation and positioning, message strategy, promotion, financial analysis and the execution of marketing strategies in the context of sport. Students will develop an understanding of how marketing works in sports through readings, lectures, case analysis and discussions with guest experts.

overview_of_class: Sponsored by the Medill-McCormick Center for Innovation in Technology, Media and Journalism. In this one-unit course, cross-functional teams of journalism and computer science students collaborate in the creation of working tools aimed at the generation, presentation and deployment of news and information. The emphasis is on building tools to assist journalists in the performance of their daily tasks, e.g. in conjunction with a large-scale database system, or in the development of a Web-based application. The objective is to develop a set of skills that will allow students to do problem-solving in information access and management, and to share responsibility with team members in the framing, architecture, management, and implementation of technology-based projects.
